messages.text: When Leah wakes up, she sees a voice message from Rem. She presses play.
Remâ€™s voice is deep and sexy, and smooth and refined.
Good morning! I wanted you to hear my voice. Fair is fair, you knowâ€¦
And I always reciprocate.
I hope my story last night didnâ€™t scare you. Thatâ€™s my past, and I try not to dwell on it.
I have demons, of course, but everyone does, donâ€™t they?
When the message is over, Leah pauses.
Then she records her own voice message. Her voice is still husky with sleep.
Morning, Rem. Yes, everyone has demons and secrets and scarsâ€¦
And sometimes, they donâ€™t want to talk about them.
She takes a deep breath before continuing.
I do, too, if Iâ€™m being honest.
She presses send, and then stares at the reflection of her scar in the screen of her phone.
She runs her finger along it. Without the scar, sheâ€™d be so pretty. She knows that.
But with itâ€¦sheâ€™s flawed.
She needs to put an end to this flirtation before her feelings get seriously hurt.
Taking another deep breath, she sends another voice text.
Would you like to get drinks tonight?
Itâ€™ll be like pulling off a Band-Aid, she tells herself.
She envisions the look that might be on his face when he first sees herâ€¦
Heâ€™ll be crestfallen and disappointed.
Her heart drops.
A text comes in, another voice message from Rem. She plays it.
I have a dinner meeting, but I can definitely meet you for drinks afterward.
Does that work for you?
He pauses.
And Leah, being afraid of losing your virginity isnâ€™t really a demon.
Itâ€™s natural, I promise. Hell, I was scared to lose mine.
I was afraid I wouldnâ€™t do it rightâ€”
That it would be too fast, that I would disappoint the girl I was with at the time.
Please donâ€™t worry about anything. Iâ€™ll be gentle, and weâ€™ll go slow.
If at any point, you want to stop and wait, weâ€™ll do that. Instantly.
You have nothing to worry about.
Leah listens to his message, and her eyes well up.
He thinks that the only thing she has to worry about is losing her virginityâ€¦
And at this point, she doesnâ€™t even care about that.
A stronger emotion has taken hold of herâ€”
So before she can second-guess herself, she presses the record button.
Rem, Iâ€™m not afraid of losing my virginity to you.
This might scare you, but Iâ€™m going to tell you somethingâ€¦
I like you.
Like, really like you.
This started out as a way to lose my virginity in a perfunctory way, but this past weekâ€¦
Iâ€™ve grown to really like you as a person.
Every time I get a text from you, my heart speeds up and I get butterflies in my stomach.
Losing my virginity to you will be wonderful. I know that. Iâ€™m not afraid at all.
She pauses.
The only thing Iâ€™m worried aboutâ€¦is losing you.
Before I even really get a chance to know you.
She presses send and Rem answers almost immediately.
Iâ€™m intrigued by you, Leah.
Youâ€™ve been on my mind more than Iâ€™d like to admit. I think of you constantlyâ€”
And I donâ€™t even have a face to put to your voice. That doesnâ€™t matter to me.
I want to see you tomorrow night.
Would you like to meet at Spill bar for drinks around 8?
You should probably see my face nowâ€¦
So you know who to look for.
A picture of his face comes in over text message.
Leahâ€™s breath catches in her throat as she stares at the handsome man staring back at her.
Heâ€™s got early morning stubble, rich chestnut hair, warm eyes and a chiseled jaw.
Her heart sinks into her belly. A man like that would never want her â€” ever.
Too afraid to speak, she texts him back.
Youâ€™re beautiful, Rem.
ðŸ˜‚ Men arenâ€™t beautiful, Leah.
But you are.
I have to tell you something, Rem. Noâ€”
I have to show you something.
And once you see itâ€¦
You might not want to meet with me.
I totally understand if that happens. This is my secret, Rem.
Leah draws in a ragged breath.
She takes a selfie that clearly depicts her entire face, including her scar.
She smiles in the picture â€” but she doesnâ€™t see her full lips, rosy cheeks and sparkling eyes.
All she can see is the monster on her cheekbone.
She sends the picture, and quickly types a series of follow-up messages.
Iâ€™ll be tied up all day today.
If you still want to meet me after seeing this, Iâ€™ll be at Spill bar tonight at 8pm.
I really hope I see you.
But like I said, if you donâ€™t want to after thisâ€¦
I completely understand.
Leah powers off her phone.
Thereâ€™s no way she can deal with the rejection right nowâ€”
Not after opening her heart like she did.
She gets ready for work, avoiding the temptation to turn her phone back on.
She imagines the excuses Rem might have textedâ€¦
And her stomach clenches. Maybe she wonâ€™t even hear from him again.
If thatâ€™s the case, she tells herself, so be it. She squares her shoulders and drives to work.
At work, Leahâ€™s day drags on and during lunch, she eats alone in her classroom.
Thirty minutes in to the period, her friend Julie pokes her head in.
As soon as she sees Leahâ€™s face, she comes in and sits down.
Whatâ€™s wrong?
Leah rocks forward.
Iâ€™m nervous.
About what?
You remember the guy I mentioned?
The one Iâ€™ve been talking to online?
Julie nods.
I really like him. Heâ€™s pretty damned perfect.
And I finally sent him a picture this morning.
And? Whatâ€™s the problem?
I donâ€™t know how heâ€™ll react.
Julie pauses.
To what?
Leah stares at her, annoyed. She hates pussy-footing around her obvious shortcoming.
To my scar.
Oh my God! Are you being serious??
Julie looks at Leahâ€™s face and realizes that she is dead serious.
Leah, youâ€™re beautiful. I never even see the scar anymore.
Thatâ€™s only because you know me.
Iâ€™m sure when you first met me, it was all you saw.
Not really. Itâ€™s there, of courseâ€”
But itâ€™s so thin and faint. I think youâ€™ve built it up in your head to be something it isnâ€™t.
You donâ€™t understand. Even Michael brought it up â€” everyone sees it.
Oh my God. I didnâ€™t know you were so self-conscious about it!
Youâ€™re so beautiful that I thought you surely knew that.
Honestly. Iâ€™d trade places with you in a heartbeat â€” scar and all.
Then youâ€™re crazy.
No, itâ€™s the truth.
Let me guess â€” you havenâ€™t given the guy a chance to respond.
Leah looks up at her friend guiltily.
I turned my phone off after I sent the photo.
Julie throws her head back in exasperation.
Thank God I came in here.
Now do yourself a favor and check to see what he said.
No. I canâ€™t yet. Iâ€™ve got to steel myself first.
Weâ€™re supposed to meet tonight. If heâ€™s not there, then Iâ€™ll know.
Iâ€™ll never have to read his lame excuses.
But Leah, youâ€™re creating a problem that isnâ€™t even there.
Youâ€™re going to worry all day.
So be it. Iâ€™d rather do it this way.
Julie shakes her head but stops arguing. She gets to her feet and heads to the door.
But before she leaves, she makes one final statement.
Anyone would be lucky to be with you, Leah.
I wish that you could see that.
But Leah is already staring out the window, and her stomach has tied itself in knots.
